data.title: Tesla recalls 817,000 vehicles in U.S. over seat belt reminder alert
data.description: Tesla Inc is recalling more than 817,000 vehicles in the United States because an audible alert may not activate when a vehicle starts and the driver has not buckled the seat belt, a U.S. auto safety regulator said.

data.title: Meta pauses new users from joining analytics tool CrowdTangle
data.description: Facebook's parent company Meta Platforms Inc has paused new users from joining its social media tracking tool CrowdTangle due to staffing constraints.

data.title: Robinhood posts $423 million net loss, shares sink after hours
data.description: Commission-free brokerage Robinhood Markets Inc on Thursday posted a $423 million net loss in the latest quarter, and its shares tumbled as much as 15% in after-hours trade even as revenue edged past analysts' estimates.

data.author: Darshan A Nakhwa
data.title: Q3 Results Preview: India Inc.’s Ebitda Margin To Shrink First Time In 12 Quarters: Crisil
data.description: Q3 Results Preview: India Inc.’s Ebitda Margin To Shrink First Time In 12 Quarters: Crisil

data.title: Macy's shortens store hours as COVID-19 cases surge
data.description: Macy's Inc will reduce its US store hours for the rest of January as it prepares for potential COVID-19 cases among workers with the Omicron variant driving up infections across the United States.

data.title: Tesla recalls 475,000 vehicles due to camera and frunk issues
data.description: Over 475,000 Tesla Inc (TSLA) cars have been recalled due to technical defects that may increase the risk of accidents. Two separate recalls are in place, one regarding the rear-view camera in the Tesla Model 3 and the other involves the frunk, or front trunk, latches in the Model S.

data.author: Azman Usmani
data.title: Time's Running Out For India Inc. To Split The CEO And Chairperson Roles
data.description: Time's Running Out For India Inc. To Split The CEO And Chairperson Roles

data.title: Alphabet CEO Pichai can be questioned in privacy lawsuit, judge rules
data.description: Plaintiffs who accused Alphabet Inc's Google of unlawfully tracking their internet use while on "Incognito" browsing mode can question Chief Executive Sundar Pichai for up to two hours, a California federal judge has ruled.

data.author: Samson Ellis
